abstract: Jehovah Witnesses who avoid South Korea’s military conscription as conscientious objectors face imprisonment, bias and other abuses; yearly average of 600-700 conscientious objectors are sent to South Korean prisons, but denomination is hopeful Constitutional Court, who is holding public hearings on the matter, will rule in their favor allowing them to serve in non-military way.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s imprisoned Jehovah’s Witnesses reportedly account for more than 90 percent of all imprisoned conscientious objectors in the world.

headline.main: South Korean Jehovah’s Witnesses Face Stigma of Not Serving in Army
headline.print_headline: South Korean Jehovah’s Witnesses Fight Stigma of Not Serving in Army

snippet: South Korea’s imprisoned Jehovah’s Witnesses reportedly account for more than 90 percent of all imprisoned conscientious objectors in the world.
